world_news:
• Gaza Ceasefire Talks: Hamas has responded to the US-backed ceasefire proposal, seeking amendments that include a timeline for a permanent truce and the complete withdrawal of Israeli troops from Gaza. US Secretary of State Antony Blinken stated that while some changes are workable, others are not, and negotiations are ongoing to bridge the gaps.
  • G7 Agrees on $50B Loan for Ukraine: Leaders of the G7 nations have agreed to a US-backed plan to provide a $50 billion loan to Ukraine, using interest earned from frozen Russian assets as collateral. The funds are intended to support Ukraine's defense, economy, and reconstruction efforts amidst the ongoing war.
  • US Inflation Cools, Fed Holds Rates: The latest US inflation data showed a surprising slowdown in May, but the Federal Reserve opted to keep interest rates unchanged. The central bank signaled that it now anticipates only one rate cut in 2024, down from a previous projection of three, as it seeks more confidence that inflation is moving sustainably toward its 2% target.
  • UN Report Accuses Israel and Hamas of War Crimes: A United Nations commission of inquiry has concluded that both Israeli authorities and Hamas committed war crimes and crimes against humanity since the October 7 attacks. The report cited Hamas for acts including murder and torture, and Israel for actions such as extermination, using starvation as a weapon, and forcible transfer.
  • Deadly Fire in Kuwait: A fire in a building housing foreign workers in Mangaf, southern Kuwait, has killed at least 49 people and injured dozens more. Most of the victims were reportedly Indian nationals. Authorities have launched an investigation into the cause, with initial reports suggesting building code violations may have been a factor.
  • French Political Turmoil Deepens: France's mainstream conservative party, Les Républicains, is in disarray after its leader, Éric Ciotti, was ousted by the party's political committee for attempting to form an electoral alliance with Marine Le Pen's far-right National Rally ahead of snap legislative elections.
  • Argentina's Senate Approves Milei's Reforms: Argentina's Senate narrowly passed President Javier Milei's controversial economic reform package after a day of violent clashes between protesters and police in Buenos Aires. The 'omnibus' bill, key to Milei's austerity and deregulation agenda, will now return to the lower house for final approval.
  • EU to Impose Tariffs on Chinese EVs: The European Union announced it will impose additional tariffs of up to 38.1% on imported Chinese electric vehicles starting in July. The move follows an investigation that found Chinese EV makers benefit from unfair government subsidies, escalating trade tensions between Brussels and Beijing.
  • Russian Missile Strike Kills Civilians in Kryvyi Rih: A Russian missile attack on a residential building in Kryvyi Rih, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy's hometown, killed at least nine people and injured 29 others. The strike is one of the deadliest in recent weeks as Russia continues its aerial bombardment of Ukrainian cities.
  • Houthi Rebels Strike Greek-Owned Ship in Red Sea: Yemen's Houthi rebels claimed responsibility for a sea drone and missile attack that caused severe flooding and damage to a Greek-owned coal carrier, the Tutor, in the Red Sea. The crew was forced to abandon the vessel, marking a significant escalation in Houthi attacks on commercial shipping.
us_news:
• Hunter Biden Convicted: A federal jury in Delaware found Hunter Biden, the president's son, guilty on all three felony charges related to illegally purchasing a firearm in 2018 while being a user of illicit drugs. This marks the first time the child of a sitting U.S. president has been convicted of a crime.
  • Inflation Cools Unexpectedly: The latest Consumer Price Index (CPI) report showed that inflation cooled in May, with prices remaining flat from the previous month and the annual rate easing to 3.3%. The better-than-expected data could influence the Federal Reserve's upcoming interest rate decisions.
  • Hamas Responds to Ceasefire Plan: Hamas submitted its formal response to the U.S.-backed Gaza ceasefire proposal, suggesting 'amendments' that include a clearer timeline for a permanent ceasefire and the complete withdrawal of Israeli troops. U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken stated that while some changes are workable, others are not.
  • Primary Election Results: Voters in Nevada, South Carolina, North Dakota, and Maine cast their ballots in primary elections. Notable results include Army veteran Sam Brown winning the Republican nomination to challenge Democratic Senator Jacky Rosen in Nevada, and Rep. Nancy Mace winning her GOP primary in South Carolina against a challenger backed by Kevin McCarthy.
  • Federal Reserve Holds Rates Steady: The Federal Reserve concluded its two-day policy meeting by keeping its benchmark interest rate unchanged. Citing still-elevated inflation, officials signaled they now expect to cut rates only once in 2024, down from a previous projection of three cuts.
  • Apple Stock Hits Record High: Following its AI-focused Worldwide Developers Conference, Apple's stock surged more than 7% to close at an all-time high. Investors reacted positively to the newly unveiled 'Apple Intelligence' features, anticipating they will drive a significant iPhone upgrade cycle.
  • Supreme Court Gun Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled 6-3 in *Kansas v. United States*, making it easier to secure longer sentences for criminals who use firearms in their offenses. The decision broadens the scope of what qualifies as a federal gun crime under the Armed Career Criminal Act.
  • Chiquita Brands Found Liable: A federal jury in Florida found Chiquita Brands International liable for financing a Colombian paramilitary group, the United Self-Defense Forces of Colombia (AUC), which was designated a terrorist organization. The company was ordered to pay $38.3 million to the families of eight victims.
  • Southwest Heatwave Intensifies: An oppressive heatwave continues to bake the southwestern U.S., with excessive heat warnings in effect for over 20 million people. Cities like Phoenix and Las Vegas are experiencing dangerously high temperatures, exceeding 110 degrees Fahrenheit.
  • Austin Approves New Ukraine Aid: Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin approved a new $225 million military aid package for Ukraine. The package includes munitions for High Mobility Artillery Rocket Systems (HIMARS) and other critical artillery rounds and missiles as Ukraine defends against Russian advances near Kharkiv.
tech_news:
• OpenAI GPT-5: OpenAI announced it has begun training its next-generation AI model, expected to be GPT-5, and is forming a new Safety and Security Committee to oversee the project's risks.
  • AI Voice Controversy: Scarlett Johansson issued a statement saying OpenAI's 'Sky' voice was 'eerily similar' to her own, after she had declined an offer to voice the system. OpenAI has since paused the use of the voice.
  • Windows 11 Recall Privacy: Microsoft's new AI-powered 'Recall' feature for Copilot+ PCs is facing significant privacy concerns from security experts, as it takes constant screenshots of user activity to create a searchable timeline.
  • Apple iOS 17.5.1: Apple released iOS 17.5.1 and iPadOS 17.5.1, an important bug fix update that addresses an issue where deleted photos could reappear in the Photos library.
  • xAI Funding: Elon Musk's artificial intelligence startup xAI is reportedly closing in on a $6 billion funding round that would value the company at $24 billion, signaling continued massive investment in the AI sector.
  • Adobe Photoshop AI: Adobe has rolled out major updates to Photoshop's generative AI features, including a new 'Reference Image' tool that allows users to upload an image to guide the style of AI-generated content.
  • Google AI Overviews: Google's new 'AI Overviews' in search results are causing controversy, with some instances showing inaccurate or bizarre answers, prompting discussions about the reliability of AI-generated summaries.
  • Humane Seeks Sale: Just over a month after launching its Ai Pin, reports indicate that the wearable AI device company Humane is already looking for a buyer, with an asking price between $750 million and $1 billion.
  • Amazon's AI Alexa: Amazon is planning a major overhaul for its Alexa voice assistant, incorporating more advanced conversational AI and reportedly considering a monthly subscription fee for the premium version.
  • TSMC's New Chip Tech: TSMC has revealed a new silicon process for creating chips with over a trillion transistors, paving the way for more powerful and complex AI hardware in the coming years.
